headline: Ex-Wolves player hints Ruben Neves has picked next club after Man Utd transfer links
body: Ruben Neves will join Real Madrid on a free transfer in a blow to Manchester United's hopes, according to former Al Hilal player Al Jaber. The Red Devils were eyeing Neves' dwindling contract as a potential opportunity.

Neves, 28, would cost in the region of £20million to sign from Al Hilal with his deal set to expire in little over six months. The former Wolves star could bring significant wage demands after commanding £350,000-a-week in Saudi Arabia, however.

Signing a central midfielder is a priority for United, who have been linked with a number of players including Carlos Baleba, Conor Gallagher, Adam Wharton and Elliot Anderson. It appears Neves could prove elusive, with Los Blancos open to securing a low-risk, high-reward deal.

Jaber, who also spent time at Molineux in 2000, claimed on MBC that Neves is set to leave for free and will join the Spanish giants. “I fear Neves will move from Al Hilal to Real Madrid for free after his contract expires at the end of this season," he said.
"There are English Premier League clubs that want to sign Neves, offering three-year contracts – until he is 31. There is Real Madrid, and I’m sure there are other clubs interested in Neves.”

The news will come as a blow after it emerged that Bournemouth winger Antoine Semenyo is set to choose Manchester City over Old Trafford. The Cherries ace is keen to head to the Etihad and is available £65m in the summer.

Ruben Amorim met with Semenyo in the summer, but United's attempts appear to have failed. The Portuguese coach has been coy over the club's January plans but only wants players who will impact United in the long term.
"We'll see," Amorim said when asked if money was available for the transfer window. "The only thing we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think are going to be the future.

"It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON. "It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that we need more.
"We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that are perfect for our future. I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."

headline: Antoine Semenyo says NO to Man Utd transfer as first preference on January move emerges
body: Antoine Semenyo has his heart set on a move to Manchester City in January. The Bournemouth forward is one of the most sought after players in the Premier League after another impressive season on the south coast.

The 25-year-old signed a new deal with the Cherries in July, helping to fend off interest from a host of clubs during the summer window. However, part of that arrangement included a clause which will allow Semenyo to leave for £65million at the start of 2026.

A host of clubs have been in the mix to sign the Ghana international, including both Manchester United and City. However, the Athletic report that Semenyo's preference would be to play for Pep Guardiola in the blue half of the city.

United had made a hard play to sign the standout Cherries star, but there was always an acceptance a deal would be hard. And a desire to immediately compete for the game's top prizes is said to have played a deciding factor in his final choice.
Liverpool are also understood to be admirers of the players, while Chelsea made tentative enquiries for a player who already has eight Premier League goals this season.

Guardiola had previously hinted that City could be set for a quieter January window, after green lighting a huge spending spree 12 months ago. That was in the midst of a crippling injury crisis, while City are in a much stronger position this time around.

He said: “Listen, last season what happened in the transfer window was for just one reason – we have (had) no players. Old players and no players, old players and no players. And you have to, you know, for the next years, new vibes, new energy – that was the reason why. But I’m not a big, big, big, big fan for the (January) transfer window.

“Always you have to be open, you never know what happens, and it’s possible that the club decides it’s good for now and for the next three, four, five, six years – why not? But it’s better to, you know, at the end of the season to see what happened this season, how it was. It’s much better.”

Bournemouth have been resigned to the fact that they could lose their star player, who they signed from Bristol City for around £10m in 2023. Speaking on Tuesday, manager Andoni Iraola said he was desperate to keep Semenyo, but couldn't 'control' what would happen when the window opens on January 1.

"Antoine Semenyo right now is with us, he's playing very well, he's playing very well,” the Spaniard said. “I understand that there is a lot of noise around Antoine, but my concern is that it doesn't affect him, his performances, and we are seeing that it's not affecting his performances.

"He's very committed to the team and I hope we can keep him there. There are situations that I cannot control or we cannot control, but right now Antoine is our player and he's going to continue playing for us. If you ask me, I don't want to lose him, definitely I don't want to lose him.
"But like we always say, every time the market opens, you never know what's going to happen. I think it's no secret that he's a massive player for us."
He added: "At the end of situations, myself as a coach, I don't control, I'm not in the negotiations when the players negotiate with the club and they find agreements.

"When you sign a contract, both parties are happy when you sign the contract. But me as a coach, I can only tell you I hope we don't lose him, because it's very, very important for us. But I don't know, I cannot control what's going to happen."

headline: Antoine Semenyo's Chelsea comments resurface after entering Liverpool and Man Utd race
body: With a host of Premier League clubs vying for Antoine Semenyo's signature, it remains uncertain where he may end up when the January transfer window closes. The Bournemouth forward has been a revelation in the Premier League this season, with his once erratic shooting in the final third now a thing of the past.

Semenyo's tally of eight goals and three assists from 16 appearances has sparked a flurry of interest in clubs securing his services. Arsenal, Manchester United, Liverpool, Tottenham and Manchester City have all been strongly linked, but it appears only three clubs are still in contention.

Yet it seems that might have been a slip of the tongue, as Semenyo, who has been spotted at the Emirates Stadium, once explicitly stated that he supports Arsenal. In a 2024 interview with The Athletic, he said: "I am an Arsenal fan.

"I don't conflict the two with my job. It is great to play against Arsenal, a team I have watched all my life and I want to play for the top clubs as well. In order for that to happen I need to prove it."

When quizzed about whether joining the Gunners would be his dream, Semenyo responded: "Yeah, any team that plays Champions League, Europa (League) - that's the aim. I know that's not going to come with a click of my fingers, it's going to take some time.
"It's going to take goals. It's going to take a lot of consistent performances. But I've worked all my life for that and I'm just going to continue working hard. That's my mentality."

Semenyo seems to have his pick of three Champions League teams, provided they're willing to activate the £65million release clause in his contract come early January. After several standout performances, it appears the Cherries have resigned themselves to losing him, with Andoni Iraola unable to confirm otherwise.
At a press conference, he said: "At the end, in the situation, myself as a coach, I don't control. When you sign a contract, I understand both parties are happy when you sign it.
"But me as a coach, I can only tell you I hope we don't lose him, because he is very important for us. But I don't know what is going to happen."

headline: Ruben Amorim's nightmare Man Utd situation gets worse as Alan Shearer left in no doubt
body: Alan Shearer says Bruno Fernandes' injury will undoubtedly prove costly for Manchester United in the coming weeks. The midfielder sustained a hamstring problem during United's 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa in the Premier League at the weekend.

Since joining the club, Fernandes has been an indispensable figure for United, with his remarkable availability being one of his greatest strengths. The Portugal international has been absent for just two fixtures due to injury since his arrival at Old Trafford in 2020 and it was reported on Tuesday he could miss the next six matches.

United face a hectic schedule over the festive period with four games in 12 days. United host Newcastle on Boxing Day before welcoming Wolves to Old Trafford four days later. Trips to Leeds United and Burnley then follow in 2026.

Ruben Amorim is already managing without several crucial players who are away competing at the Africa Cup of Nations, including Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui, who are all representing their nations. United are also without Kobbie Mainoo, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt through injury, but Shearer has highlighted why Fernandes' absence in particular will prove damaging for the team.

"Losing Bruno Fernandes at any time would be bad but losing him when you're already missing three players in Mazraoui, Diallo, and Mbeumo, will hurt Man United," Shearer told Betfair. "He's been the one constant through all their troubles, the one pulling them through games at times.
"There's no doubt they'll miss him massively. He very rarely gets injured, so he'll be a big miss.
"Performance-wise, I thought Man United did alright against Villa, but the result was decided by Morgan Rogers. With injuries and people away, Newcastle are the same.
"They have massive injuries defensively, but Lewis Miley was brilliant at right-back. He was one of the best players on the park. Both teams are struggling because of injury situations."

As Shearer rightly points out, a staggering 14 players could be unavailable for United's clash against Newcastle United. Following the weekend's defeat to Villa, Amorim revealed that he anticipates Fernandes will be unavailable for that clash, though he declined to specify an exact timeframe for his return.
"It's a soft tissue, I think he's [Fernandes] going to lose some games, I don't know for sure. Let's see," Amorim said.
"I don't know. I don't want to talk about matters you can't control. He is a guy who is always fit so he might recover quite well.
"I think Kobbie might be out [against Newcastle], Bruno is out, so we will see, we are going to find solutions, no excuses, we need to win the next game and we will try to win the next game."

headline: Chelsea launch shock Antoine Semenyo transfer bid in race involving Man Utd and Liverpool
body: Chelsea have emerged as contenders to sign Antoine Semenyo by launching a late bid to sign the Bournemouth star. Semenyo, 25, is wanted by a cluster of Premier League clubs including Manchester United, Manchester City, Liverpool and Tottenham.

The London-born Ghana international is available for £65million due to a release clause which activates on New Year's Day. The clause will only be active until the second week of January, though, giving Bournemouth ample time to sign a replacement.

A departure next month looks increasingly likely, although Chelsea weren't among the favourites to sign him - until now. Several outlets are reporting that the Blues entered the race on Monday evening after Semenyo and his representatives had spent the day weighing up their options.

The Mail report that Semenyo has an affiliation with Chelsea, having been born in West London. The 25-year-old came through the ranks of Bristol City before joining Bournemouth for £10m two years ago.

Semenyo's release clause, which is specified as £60m plus £5m in add-ons, will be reduced in the summer transfer window, but interested clubs are increasingly wary that by then it could be too late. The forward has scored eight goals and provided three assists in 17 games for Bournemouth this season.

The Cherries are reluctant to lose Semenyo, especially having lost four key players over the summer, but they're ultimately powerless if a suitor activates his clause. Speaking on Tuesday afternoon, Bournemouth manager Andoni Iraola commented: "Semenyo right now is with us. He trained today with us
"I know that there is lots of noise around him. Not my concern, my concern is it doesn't affect his performances. It is not doing, he is very committed to the team and I hope we can keep him here.

"(It's a) situation we cannot control, but Antoine right now is our player. Going to continue playing for us. If you ask me, I don't want to lose him, definitely don't. But every time the market opens, you never know what is going to happen.

"Antoine, for me, has been performing very well. Not just the last two games where he has scored. He has consistently been very good since the beginning. Even when not scoring, he is still valuable for us. At the end, we don’t just demand numbers. It is no secret he is a massive player for us."
Iraola can understand why so many clubs are interested, adding: "Yes, he is performing amazingly well. But lots of wingers from other teams are performing amazingly well.
"In the league, nearly all teams have a difference maker. Especially offensively. I don’t know what is going to happen in the winter market."

headline: 'I worked with Marcus Rashford - this one thing caused him to leave Man Utd'
body: Joleon Lescott admits he's not shocked by the impressive form Marcus Rashford is showing at Barcelona. The Manchester United loanee made the switch to Spain this summer.
After falling down the pecking order under Ruben Amorim, Rashford initially joined Aston Villa on a temporary basis in January before securing another loan move to Barcelona in July.

Since arriving at the Catalan club, Rashford has been given substantial playing time. Hansi Flick has put his faith in the 28-year-old on the left wing whilst Raphinha has been sidelined and he's also been used as a striker. Rashford has netted seven goals and contributed 11 assists across all competitions this season.

Whilst his opportunities on the pitch might diminish now that Brazilian star Raphinha has returned from injury, Rashford has demonstrated his worth as a key part of Flick's squad. However, Lescott, who previously worked alongside Rashford with England, isn't taken aback by the United forward's displays.

"I'm not surprised by what he's doing over there," Lescott said, speaking on In The Mixer, brought to you by Sky Bet. "I believe Marcus Rashford makes a good team better. I don't think he makes ok teams better.

"Because the emphasis on him at Man United was that he had to do everything. I don't think he had that in his game. Whereas I think if he's in a good team and you want him to do certain things, he can do them. Then that team will be a lot better with him."
Ex-Manchester City defender Lescott even confessed that when rumours emerged about Rashford's potential departure from United, he was eager for his former club to snap up the England international.
"When there was speculation, and it wasn't a lot, about him maybe coming to Manchester City, I would've wanted to sign him that day. I would've signed him," Lescott revealed.

"I doubt he would've gone, but he definitely would've made City better. You look at what he's doing at Barcelona. They have Raphinha. And Raphinha was sensational last year and they haven't got any worse when Rashford is in there. He's obviously a top top player."
Rashford was relegated to the substitutes' bench during Barcelona's most recent victory at Villarreal, but manager Flick has already made clear precisely what the 28-year-old brings to the side.

"I try to speak to every player when they are not selected. The last time I checked with him he said, 'Boss, you don't have to tell me about your decisions. The most important thing is the team. We have to win the three points. The rest is not that important,'" Flick explained.

"This is the perfect mentality. I am so happy to have him. When he is on the bench, he shows that we have a good and deep squad. What I can say is that he is an absolutely professional player. In the beginning, he had to adapt a little bit, but now he is at his best level."

headline: Antonio Conte launches fresh Man Utd dig after latest Napoli triumph
body: Antonio Conte had a dig at Manchester United after two ex-Old Trafford stars helped Napoli emulate Diego Maradona and win the Italian Supercoppa. The former Chelsea and Spurs boss led the southern giant to the Scudetto in his first season in 2024/25 with Romelu Lukuku top scorer.

And now Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund - who was loaned after the Belgian suffered a thigh injury in pre-season - have starred in the 2-0 win over Bologna in Saudi Arabia. The Scotland star was named Serie A player of the year after netting 13 goals from midfield after his £25.7million sale by United in August 2024.

And Hojlund, who cost the Old Trafford club £72m, has now scored seven times back in Italy as Napoli won the Scudetto and the Supercoppa in the same year for the first time since 1990 with Maradona. The Dane posted a picture of himself with the trophy on social media with the caption: "What a great decision looks like."

And Conte said: “Everyone used to say Rasmus didn’t play in Manchester, neither did McTominay, so why? Ask yourselves some questions there. The staff and I had work to do, there is a reason we are here, after all.”

Ex-Premier League stars Kevin De Bruyne, Andre Frank Zambo Anguissa and Billy Gilmour were all out injured as Brazilian David Neres scored both goals in Saudi Arabia. And Conte added: “The first goal was a moment of magic from an individual, but the other chances were all prepared by analysing how to cause problems for Bologna.

“Our job as a coach is to increase the knowledge of a player and make him stronger. I feel like everyone I worked with emerged improved, in tactical understanding and movements, but also in mentality.”

Conte, who won the Premier League and FA Cup at Chelsea, lifted his 10th major trophy - and then admitted he was motivated by his past failures. “I can tell you that nobody bothers looking up the beaten finalists, because I’ve lost many as a player and a coach and they made me more mean,” said the former Italy head coach.

“Nobody remembers I was runner-up in the World Cup, European Championship finalist, or lost three Champions League Finals. They remember that as a player I won one Champions League and one Intercontinental Cup.

“When you lose a final, it increases your determination, and you try not to experience those ugly moments again. They hurt because you know that it was a good journey, but you’ve got to put that cherry on top of the cake.”
President Aurelio de Laurentiis said: “Not since the Maradona era have we won two trophies in a year. Conte is a master.”

This latest triumph comes only six weeks after Napoli lost 2-0 at Bologna in Serie A and Conte launched a stinging attack on his player before missing training. “We must do something,” he said. “I don’t want to accompany a dead man”.
But they go into 2026 sitting third in Serie A, although they are down in 23rd in the Champions League.
Former England manager Fabio Capello told Gazzetta dello Sport: “Let’s not joke. What crisis? Napoli has excellent players and a winning coach in Conte, now Lukaku and other injured players are back.
“The Supercoppa win will be very important for the players’ mentality. A psychological turning point that will also boost them in the league.”

headline: Marcus Rashford summed up his thoughts on Man Utd with just two words and rocked club
body: A year has flown by since Marcus Rashford sent shockwaves through the football world by announcing he was ready to leave Manchester United. At the time, it seemed inconceivable that the forward, who had risen through United's youth ranks to become his boyhood club's star player, would ever depart Old Trafford, especially under such bitter circumstances while still at his physical peak.

The past 12 months have been a rollercoaster for the 28-year-old, who found himself frozen out by Ruben Amorim at United, endured a mixed loan stint at Aston Villa, and is now flourishing in Spain with Barcelona.

The England star grabbed headlines for all the wrong reasons a year ago when he was dropped from the United squad that defeated Manchester City due to his alleged poor attitude during training sessions. This came after 18 months of underwhelming performances from a player who had previously been his team's driving force.

Amorim's public criticism of the striker seemed to be the breaking point for Rashford, prompting him to take the drastic decision to end his United ordeal - through a bombshell interview with journalist Henry Winter where he announced his willingness to embrace a "new challenge."
During the interview, he admitted for the first time that he was open to leaving the club. He said: "For me, personally, I think I'm ready for a new challenge and the next steps.
"When I leave it's going to be 'no hard feelings'. You're not going to have any negative comments from me about Manchester United. That's me as a person.

"If I know that a situation is already bad I'm not going to make it worse. I've seen how other players have left in the past and I don't want to be that person. When I leave I'll make a statement and it will be from me."
Rashford also responded to Amorim's decision to drop him by stating: "It's disheartening to be left out of a derby but it's happened, we won the game so let's move on.
"It's disappointing but I'm also someone as I've got older I can deal with setbacks. What am I going to do about it? Sit there and cry about it. Or do my best the next time I'm available."

By that point, it seemed all bridges between Rashford and Amorim had been burnt, with the forward excluded from every matchday squad for the remainder of the month until December 30, 2024, when he remained on the bench as an unused substitute against Newcastle.

Having not played a single minute since December 12, Amorim, in late January, publicly addressed Rashford’s need to change aspects of his game if he had any hope of returning to the squad, saying he would rather pick his 63-year-old goalkeeping coach ahead of a "player who doesn’t give maximum effort in training".

Rashford left United for the first time at the end of the January transfer window, securing a loan move to Aston Villa until the end of the season. His stint at Villa Park allowed him to rebuild his reputation and regain visibility after his exile, especially in the Champions League against PSG.

He netted four goals and provided six assists in 940 minutes of play but his loan spell ended on a sour note due to a hamstring injury, after which he returned to Carrington. There, he was part of Amorim's five-man 'bomb squad', who were sidelined from first-team training to encourage them to seek transfers.

After biding his time for the right opportunity, Rashford secured his dream move to Barcelona in July, joining the La Liga champions on loan until the summer of 2026. In the five months since, Rashford has come close to recapturing his best form, contributing 11 assists and seven goals for the Catalans in 24 appearances.

The Englishman has made it clear he doesn't envision a return to United, expressing his wish to sign for Barcelona once his loan ends. For now, it remains uncertain whether Barcelona will activate their reported £26million option-to-buy clause, though the unlikelihood of any reconciliation with Amorim suggests Rashford will permanently leave United regardless.

headline: Man Utd 'make double transfer decision' as Kobbie Mainoo directly impacted
body: Manchester United are reportedly prepared to make major changes to their midfield in the months ahead, with such plans expected to affect Kobbie Mainoo's future. The January transfer window is fast approaching, and with it has seen increased speculation about the business that Premier League clubs may conduct.

United are reportedly expected to have a busy transfer window in the New Year, with the midfield widely talked about as an area of the squad in need of investment. Brighton's Carlos Baleba was heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford during the summer transfer window, with the Seagulls reportedly placing a valuation of more than £100million on the midfielder.

Elliot Anderson of Nottingham Forest and Adam Wharton of Crystal Palace are two other players who have been linked with United over the last few months. The Sun have reported that United are prepared to sign two midfielders ahead of the summer transfer window.

It remains to be seen, though, if those plans will involve looking to bring in midfield reinforcements in the January window. A separate report from The Times has also reported that, with the recent injury to Bruno Fernandes, it's now unlikely that Mainoo will leave United in the January window.

Mainoo has been heavily linked with a move away from United over the last few months, with the 20-year-old apparently looking for more game time after spending much of this season on the bench. Ruben Amorim has yet to hand Mainoo a start for United this season in the Premier League, but has given the England international 11 appearances as a substitute in the top flight.

United suffered a 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa in the Premier League on Sunday, where Mainoo was not available for the match due to a calf injury. Amorim stated after the defeat to Villa that he expects Fernandes to be unavailable for United for their next run of fixtures after the Red Devils captain suffered a hamstring injury over the weekend.

headline: Scott McTominay leaves Italian media in agreement with second trophy win for Napoli
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Scott McTominay produced another assured display to claim his second piece of silverware with Napoli on Monday. The Scotland international featured for the entire 90 minutes as Antonio Conte's Italian champions earned a well-deserved 2-0 victory over Bologna in the Supercoppa Italiana.

Napoli's Brazilian winger David Neres stole the headlines, netting both goals either side of the break. Yet, McTominay's display was befitting of the Serie A Footballer of the Year award he claimed for last season following his dominant league performances, having been central to several of Napoli's brightest moments once again.
The 29-year-old threaded a sublime pass to Eljif Elmas in the opening stages which sent the Macedonian clean through, though he was denied an assist as his team-mate fired wide of the target.

He came close to finding the net himself just before the break to extend Napoli's advantage but was thwarted by opposing keeper Federico Ravaglia. McTominay continued to dominate the midfield through his commanding presence and physical prowess, while proving instrumental in the team's attacking phases.
He was again denied in the 77th minute following an acrobatic effort at the far post, having played a crucial role in Neres’ second goal minutes prior after pressing Bologna’s goalkeeper.
Unsurprisingly, he received plenty of praise in the Italian press, with Corriere della Sera giving him a 7/10 match rating and referring to his "dynamism".

Corriere dello Sport also awarded him a 7/10, noting that he was "less flashy than usual in the first half but no less present." They highlighted how despite Tomasso Pobega's attempts to contain him, the Scottish international easily won their duel in the first half and upped his game after half-time.
La Repubblica gave him a match rating of 6.5, framing his performance as a Scottish showdown with fellow countryman Lewis Ferguson in midfield - a battle they believe McTominay came out on top of.
Eurosport Italy lauded McTominay, describing his performance alongside Rasmus Hojlund's as "excellent". Football Italia and Sky Sport Italy also deemed his display worthy of a 7.

Il Giornale were slightly less generous, giving him a 6.5, but agreed that he continued to provide a constant threat, writing: “McTominay wasn’t as brilliant as in other matches but still always finds ways to be dangerous.”
It appears the former United man’s form is showing no signs of letting up under the tutelage of Conte, having scored five goals and provided three assists this season across all competitions.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund pokes fun at Man Utd exit after Napoli transfer vindicated
body: Rasmus Hojlund appeared to aim a dig at Manchester United following Napoli's 2-0 Supercoppa Italiana victory over Bologna on Monday evening. David Neres netted both goals in Saudi Arabia, securing the Italian side's first trophy in the competition since 2014.
Hojlund featured for the full 90 minutes in attack as Antonio Conte's squad cruised to success. The forward joined Naples during the summer on a season-long loan deal that is set to become permanent.

It's understood that the Danish international's move to Italy will be made permanent provided certain criteria are fulfilled, including securing Champions League qualification. Hojlund managed just four goals for United last term and found himself slipping down the pecking order following Ruben Amorim's attacking restructure.

The arrivals of Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko meant Hojlund was free to leave. Mbeumo and Cunha have impressed this season, although Sesko has only managed two goals since his switch from RB Leipzig.

Sharing a photograph of himself holding the silverware, the forward captioned it: "What a great decision looks like." The post received likes from several of Hojlund's former United colleagues, including Lisandro Martinez, Chido Obi, Patrick Dorgu and Andre Onana. Both Dorgu and Obi also left comments congratulating the striker.

Following the match, Conte reflected on his team's performance and joined Hojlund in taking a dig at United. "If we look at how many chances we created, we could have been far more effective," he commented.

"We played a great match in every aspect. The first goal was a moment of brilliance from a champion; the other situations were carefully designed to put the opponents under pressure with many players around the box.

"Hojlund and McTominay were not playing at Manchester United, so there must be a reason given the work done by me and my staff. I believe our job is to expand a player's knowledge and make him stronger.

"I invest a lot in that, and I think every player I have worked with has always come out improved technically, tactically, and mentally. We lacked clinical finishing against a strong team, but it remains a great performance, and I can only be happy and proud."

headline: Man Utd news: Bruno Fernandes replacement identified as transfer tug of war breaks out
body: Manchester United could be set to add to their squad this January with the Red Devil's currently languishing in seventh in the Premier League. The club's middling run of form continued against Aston Villa on Sunday.

A Morgan Rodgers double downed Amorim's side to leave them three points off fifth. It now appears Amorim will have to cope without Bruno Fernandes for some time too, after the United skipper pulled up with a hamstring injury in the first half of the 2-1 away loss to Villa.

Reports have suggested that the United captain could be out for at least a month with a suspected soft-tissue injury. With the January transfer window approaching, rumours are swirling that United could be set to add several fresh faces to the team.

Ruben Neves is a name that's emerged as a potential target for United with Fernandes expected to miss a chunk of action. United's interest reportedly dates back to the Portuguese star's time at Wolves.
Now at Al-Hilal, the 28-year-old is being linked with a move back to the Premier League after rejecting a new deal in Saudi Arabia.

The Times have reported that Al-Hilal are resigned to losing him on a free transfer in the summer. They are said to be open to selling the player in January in an attempt to recoup some of the £47 million they paid in 2023.

United have held a long term interest in players such as Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton and Brighton's Carlos Baleba. Yet their hefty transfer tags means that cheaper options will have to be considered this winter.
A figure of £18m for Neves has been touted. However, it's believed that the midfielder could be available for much less.
Whether United make a play for Neves or not, Amorim has warned the club must not make any mistakes in the next transfer window.
"We need to deal with that," he said. "What we cannot do is reach January and try to do everything with urgency and make mistakes again and be left saying 'here we go again'.

Speaking on Fernandes, who almost left the club in the summer amidst interest from Saudi Arabia, Amorim said: "I think it's a soft-tissue injury so it's going to be a while. He is a guy who is always fit so we hope he can recover well. We will see."

United are firmly in the mix for Bournemouth star Semenyo, according to reports. However, they facee strong competition from rivals Manchester City. United boss Amorim is understood to be an admirer of the 25-year-old Ghanaian.
Several reports had claimed that Semenyo had a £100m price tag. However, it was recently confirmed he has a release clause of £60m plus £5m in add-ons.

So far this season, Semenyo boasts eight goals and three assists in the Premier League. The winger has reportedly already rejected interest from Tottenham Hotspur and is now set to decide whether to join City or United.

As per the Telegraph, Liverpool are also prepared to end their pursuit of the Bournemouth forward, providing a boost for Amorim. According to GiveMeSport, Semenyo's release clause is available for the first 10 days of the January transfer window, which begins on New Year's Day.

United have held direct talks with Bournemouth about a possible move for the forward. However, It's also understood he is yet to make his mind up on whether he wants to depart the Cherries at all next month.

headline: Liverpool get instant Alexander Isak transfer instruction after return timeframe confirmed
body: Arne Slot faces a significant transfer headache after Alexander Isak looks to be ruled out for several months, following surgery on a fractured leg. Liverpool's £125m striker was forced off against Tottenham after a heavy challenge from Micky van de Ven.

The extent of the injury has now been revealed, with Isak set to miss a substantial chunk of the season. Following an MRI scan on Sunday, the 26 year old underwent successful surgery, leaving Slot with the challenge of finding a replacement.
If there's a bright spot in Isak's predicament, it's that the setback has come just as the January transfer window is opening. That gives the Liverpool boss time to weigh up his options.

Fellow summer signing Hugo Ekitike is expected to spearhead their attack in these coming months, but Slot will likely want additional reinforcements during this period. Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher has already suggested two potential solutions.

"I think it's pretty certain now Salah will stay at Liverpool when he comes back from AFCON," the former Reds defender said on Monday Night Football. "People wanted that to happen anyway and we spoke about that last week.

"I think Harvey Elliott's situation at Aston Villa... he will probably come back to the club because he's finding it difficult at Aston Villa. There's been big talk for a long time that Liverpool are interested in [Antoine] Semenyo.

"The fact he's a wide player who can play both sides - and your two wide players are predominantly Gakpo and Salah. Both can play centre-forward and I think Liverpool will probably go more that way [in the transfer market] rather than going for a centre-forward or buying someone they don't really fancy.

"They seem to really like Semenyo, as a lot of other teams do, as well. I go back to what Liverpool did a few years ago when they had a few centre-backs out, they brought in a lad from Preston and a lad from overseas. They were never going to be Liverpool players for the future, it was to get them until the end of the season.
"Liverpool may find a striker to do that, but I don't think they'll be looking to spend big money on someone they don't particularly fancy right now."

The AFC Bournemouth attacker is, arguably, among the most coveted players in the Premier League as the January window approaches. Liverpool were rumoured to be tracking Semenyo during the summer, and those reports have persisted.

The Cherries star has a £65m release clause which will be triggered for the opening 10 days of the January transfer window. With Manchester United, Manchester City and Tottenham also, reportedly, an showing interest, Liverpool would need to act swiftly.
What might give Slot's side an advantage is Semenyo's 'preferred' destination. According to The Guardian, the forward regards Liverpool as his dream next club.

Reports also suggest that Harvey Elliott might be making a return to Anfield after a challenging loan stint at Aston Villa. The 22 year old has only made five appearances since joining Unai Emery's squad on a season-long deal.

Elliott's move will become permanent if he plays in 10 matches for Villa, but it seems Emery is hesitant to activate that clause, given that Elliott hasn't featured for them since early October. As such, discussions are reportedly underway between the two clubs about ending the loan early.
With Isak out of action for an extended period, Slot might choose to pursue Liverpool's interest in Semenyo and recall Elliott from his loan to strengthen his attacking options.

headline: Aston Villa news: Harvey Elliott's Liverpool recall clause and Emi Martinez's Man Utd gesture
body: Aston Villa are flying high in the Premier League as Unai Emery continues to work his magic. The club have won their last 10 matches in all competitions, leading to the Villans being discussed as possible title contenders.

A 2-1 victory over Manchester United established an impressive seven-point gap to Chelsea in fourth place, who are next on the horizon for Emery’s side. A positive result at Stamford Bridge this weekend will bolster their chances of securing Champions League football and fuel further talk of a title race.

With the January transfer window fast approaching, Villa have already been linked with several deals at a pivotal point in the campaign. Here is a closer look at some of the latest headlines surrounding Villa Park.

Harvey Elliott was a celebrated signing when he joined Villa on loan from Liverpool on deadline day. The deal included a £35million obligation to buy after reaching a certain number of appearances, widely expected to be a formality given his performances for Liverpool and England U21 heroics in the summer.

However, the 22-year-old has been limited to just seven appearances across all competitions. He has not featured in a Premier League matchday squad since October, leading to concerns over Elliott’s immediate future.

It has been reported that the deal between Liverpool and Villa does not include a recall clause. While it is still possible for the loan move to be cancelled, the Liverpool Echo highlights that the Reds may have already factored his sale into their financial plans.

Should the deal be cancelled, Elliott’s only option would be to return to Anfield as he featured for the Reds earlier in the season and is unable to represent a third club. This could still benefit Liverpool, with the likes of Alexander Isak, Cody Gakpo and Wataru Endo all currently dealing with injuries.

Emei Martinez could have been lining up for Manchester United against Villa if the summer transfer window had gone differently. United ultimately opted to sign Senne Lammens on deadline day rather than the Argentine goalkeeper.
BirminghamLive reports that Martinez had been open to leaving Villa this summer. However, it all seemed a distant memory as the shot-stopper danced in front of the Holte End after Sunday’s win.

The 33-year-old wore a Villa-themed Santa hat as he savoured the latest result in the club’s winning run. As fans serenaded the goalkeeper, Martinez kissed the Villa crest on the hat before throwing it back into the crowd.
The World Cup winner has mended any lingering resentment from Villa fans after considering a move away. He has featured in 13 league games so far this term, keeping four clean sheets.

Martinez’s standout moment against United saw him deny Benjamin Sesko after the striker found himself with a one-on-one chance. He will aim to produce another commanding display against Chelsea at the weekend.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo given brutal verdict after Man Utd transfer decision - 'Not doing enough'
body: Manchester United star Kobbie Mainoo has simply not done enough to warrant a starting spot this season, according to former Premier League midfielder Dan Gosling. The 20-year-old has seen his hopes of a World Cup call-up fade after falling out of favour under Ruben Amorim, leading to suggestions he might need to leave Old Trafford in January.

Mainoo has played a little over 200 minutes in the Premier League this season, with Amorim seemingly believing he doesn't have the qualities to play in a double pivot in his 3-4-2-1 system. The academy graduate's only start this term came in the Carabao Cup, where he played the full 90 minutes in a shock defeat to Grimsby Town.

"He's obviously not doing enough on the training pitch because Ruben Amorim isn't not picking him because of his personality or other personnel. He's not doing enough on the training pitch to deserve his place. It's simple as that. If you're not working as hard as you can day in and day out you're not going to play. Yes, there's competition for [Bruno] Fernandes. But there's other spots.

"There's Casemiro's spot. He was out of the spot and he's knuckled down, his performances have gotten better. His physique has gotten better. I still don't think he's the answer and Mainoo can compete with him. He can also play higher up. He's obviously not doing enough on a day-to-day basis to convince Ruben Amorim."

Mainoo looked like he might get a chance to impress on Sunday after playing half an hour in the 4-4 draw with Bournemouth a few days earlier. Casemiro's suspension meant there was a vacancy in the middle of the park, but Mainoo picked up an injury in training and missed the game.

That meant Manuel Ugarte partnered Fernandes in the middle, but the Uruguayan didn't cover himself in glory in a 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa. Furthermore, Fernandes only managed 45 minutes due to injury and will be assessed before United play Newcastle on Boxing Day.

Napoli are among the clubs linked with Mainoo, with an injury to summer signing Kevin De Bruyne leaving them in need of midfield reinforcements. However, United were unlikely to sanction an early January move even before Fernandes' injury.

United are not expected to sanction any exits before their three players involved at the Africa Cup of Nations return to club duty. Noussair Mazraoui's Morocco team began with a 2-0 victory over Comoros, while Bryan Mbeumo and Amad will both play their first game of the tournament on Christmas Eve, for Cameroon and Cote d'Ivoire respectively.
"After training, he went to the doctor. He got something in his calf," Amorim said when asked about Mainoo's absence at Villa Park. "We are going to assess but he is out of this game.
"Of course [it is bad timing], not just for the team but for him to have this problem. These are reminders that we need to focus on everything we can control and leave the rest to the destiny.
"He is going to be fine in the few weeks, I think, I don't know. Let's focus on the players that we have and are ready to play."

headline: Antoine Semenyo could decide on transfer TODAY after Man Utd and Man City talks
body: Bournemouth star Antoine Semenyo could decide on his next club as soon as today, it has been claimed. The Ghana international is one of the Premier League's most in-demand players, with a release clause making a January move away from the Vitality Stadium a strong possibility.

The Cherries will allow potential suitors to speak to their top scorer if they receive a £65million bid, but only if that bid arrives by January 10. The agreement, entered into when Semenyo signed a new deal over the summer, is thought to be designed to give Andoni Iraola's team time to find a replacement.

Manchester United and Manchester City are among the clubs to have been linked with the former Bristol City star, who has eight goals and three assists in the Premier League this season. Arsenal and Tottenham were also mentioned as potential destinations over the summer, but the Gunners' moves for Ebere Eze and Noni Madueke mean they look less likely to break the bank.

Liverpool were also linked over the summer, opting instead to move for other targets. Among them was Alexander Isak, and an injury to the Reds' record buy could prompt them to return for Semenyo in January.

Semenyo scored again over the weekend, though it wasn't enough for victory against Burnley. The goal was his second in as many matches after scoring his team's first in their 4-4 draw away to Manchester United.
After the Burnley game, Bournemouth boss Iraola was asked about interest in Semenyo. "He is a massive player for us. It is not a big secret," he said.

Over the weekend, it was reported that Manchester United were ready to go 'all out' to land Semenyo. The Red Devils added around £200m worth of attacking talent in the summer, though one of those new additions - Cameroon forward Bryan Mbeumo - is currently away at the Africa Cup of Nations.

United boss Ruben Amorim met Semenyo earlier in the year, and there have been suggestions he sees the Cherries star as someone who can operate as a wing-back after successfully moving winger Amad into a similar role.

"The only thing we know is that we only would try to bring players that we think are going to be the future," Amorim said when asked about new additions in January. "It's not going to be to save something in this moment, to cope with the losses of three players for AFCON. It’s not going to be like that, even if we try to bring one player, maybe it's not the position that we need more.
"We will try to bring now – and in the end of the season – players that are perfect for our future. I don't know what is going to happen, but it's possible that we can do something."

headline: Lisandro Martinez told Man Utd boss exactly what he thought of emergency position change
body: Lisandro Martinez is ready to step up and continue in midfield after filling in for the injured Bruno Fernandes against Aston Villa. Martinez was summoned from the bench to play in the centre of the pitch at Villa Park and could be drafted into the same role against Newcastle on Boxing Day.

Manchester United’s captain was forced off at half-time of their 2-1 defeat by Villa on Sunday in the Premier League and is facing a spell on the sidelines. Ruben Amorim has just three fit first-team midfielders for the upcoming visit of Newcastle to Old Trafford: Casemiro, Manuel Ugarte and Mason Mount.

The United manager handed debuts to academy graduates Jack Fletcher and Shea Lacey on Sunday, but it was Martinez who he turned to at half-time. The Argentina international defender only recently returned from 11 months on the sidelines with an ACL injury and acquitted himself well at Villa.

While Martinez is primarily a centre-back, he spent three years at Ajax where positional flexibility is coached and has filled in at left-back and midfield during his time at United, with his selfless attitude coming to the fore. “We have many good midfielders. Like I have said in many interviews, I will play wherever the coach wants to use me,” he said back in March 2023 when Erik ten Hag was short of options.

Playing Martinez in midfield was raised back in November and Amorim’s response suggested he is not particularly keen on the idea. “I can't say,” he said when asked about the possibility. “I think a smart, intelligent football player can play in a lot of positions, but it is not the right position for him.
“He needs more time to work there as he is not working there [currently]. But in one emergency he can play [there]. I am not thinking about that.”

Casemiro will return from suspension for the Newcastle game, but Kobbie Mainoo will miss the game after injury struck at the worst possible time for the 20-year-old, who has been frustrated sitting on the bench all season.

“I will see what we’re going to do,” Amorim said on Sunday. “I think Kobbie Mainoo is out and Bruno is out. So we will see. We are going to find solutions. No excuses. We need to win the next game and we will try to win the next game.”

Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire are also on the sidelines with injuries, while Amad, Bryan Mbeumo and Noussair Mazraoui are away playing at the Africa Cup of Nations. The combination has left Amorim extremely short of options, especially considering his low opinion of the level of academy players.

Nevertheless, the United boss has confirmed he won’t turn to the January transfer window to solve the crisis. “What we cannot do is to reach January and try to do everything in urgency and make mistakes and then [it’s] ‘here we go again’ with a lot of mistakes,” Amorim said. “I’m not going to get [together] with [club chiefs] Jason [Wilcox] and Omar [Berrada] and say: ‘We need a lot of players.’ Because we have a plan.

“If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in a moment where we need points but we need to find solutions and we are going to continue with our plan. You can feel in this moment that we are going to struggle, but we will see. We have to deal with it.”

headline: Bruno Fernandes 'emergency replacement' identified after Man Utd transfer statement
body: Gary Neville has tipped Lisandro Martinez to be an 'emergency replacement' for Bruno Fernandes at Manchester United. Since his transfer from Sporting Lisbon in 2020, the 31-year-old has been a constant presence for the Reds.

However, it seems manager Ruben Amorim will have to manage without him for a while, following the United captain's hamstring injury during the first half of the 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa. Remarkably, over a five-year period, Fernandes has only missed two matches due to injury.

With Kobbie Mainoo sidelined with a calf injury before the match at Villa Park and Casemiro suspended, Amorim had to think outside the box by fielding central defender Martinez alongside Manuel Ugarte. After the Argentine's impressive performance in midfield, Neville believes he could be a viable option in that position.

On the Gary Neville podcast, the ex-United skipper said: "At half-time, maybe I was thrown by the fact when Bruno Fernandes initially pulled up with his hamstring, he sent Joshua Zirkzee out to warm up. I thought, 'Yeah, that's right, because he can drop in.'

"I also liked the idea of having Mason Mount and Zirkzee behind Sesko, and Zirkzee and Sesko being potential threats from crosses, you've got running into the box, with Mount maybe dropping deeper and playing alongside Ugarte.

"When I saw Martinez come on, I thought 'How are United going to get a goal? How are they really going to pose a threat?' Now they didn't really pose a threat until that one chance Cunha got, which was a massive chance by the way.

"I would have liked to have seen Mount and Zirkzee off Sesko with Cunha floating in and around them. He didn't go for it, but I think Martinez, when he came on in the holding position, Villa did not put any real pressure on him.
"I thought he was good on the ball, I thought he was tidy. He did a good job in there. Maybe that's something that will have to happen.

"Although Casemiro will be back soon as well, so I don't think we will see him in there too much. But it's potentially one thing Amorim could do in an emergency if it happens over the Christmas period."
Fernandes and Mainoo are both expected to miss the Boxing Day match against Newcastle United. Mainoo picked up a calf injury during training ahead of the Villa encounter.

Casemiro will return from suspension, but the out-of-form Ugarte is the only other available central midfielder for the game against Eddie Howe's side. Nevertheless, Amorim made it clear Fernandes' injury will not change United's approach in the January transfer window.

Speaking after the match, Amorim said: "What we cannot do is to reach January and try to do everything in urgency and make mistakes. And then here we go again with a lot of mistakes. I'm not going to get with Jason under Omar and I'm going to say we need a lot of players because we have a plan.

"If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in the moment that we need points, but we need to find solutions and we are going to continue with our plan. Of course, you can feel that in this moment we are going to struggle, but we'll see."

headline: Man Utd could land bargain Bruno Fernandes transfer replacement after contract rejection
body: Manchester United and Ruben Amorim are facing the prospect of entering 2026 without star player Bruno Fernandes, who suffered a muscle injury in Sunday's Premier League loss to Aston Villa. Fernandes sustained the injury towards the end of the first half at Villa Park and was substituted at half-time.
Reports suggest that the United skipper could be sidelined for at least a month. "I think it's a soft-tissue injury so it's going to be a while," Amorim revealed after the match.
"He is a guy who is always fit so we hope he can recover well. We will see. It's an injury and sometimes it's bad luck or something else at the same time. You can never control these things.

"We will need to find solutions and we cannot use anything as an excuse. We need to prepare all the guys that we have for the next game. No one is going to remember these problems, so let's cope with that. It will make us stronger."

The timing of Fernandes' injury is unfortunate, coming just days before the January transfer window opens, and calls for a new midfielder to be signed as a priority at Old Trafford are likely to intensify. However, Amorim has insisted that the club must avoid making any errors in the upcoming transfer window.
"We need to deal with that. What we cannot do is reach January and try to do everything with urgency and make mistakes again and be left saying 'here we go again'," he stated.

"I am not going to go to Jason [Wilcox] and say we need a lot of players. If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in the moment that we need points, but we are going to continue with our plan. In this moment, you may feel we are going to struggle, but we will see."

The impact of Fernandes' injury on United's transfer plans remains uncertain. With doubts surrounding Kobbie Mainoo and Casemiro, a new midfielder was already high on their agenda, but the Fernandes problem has made the situation more urgent.

Fortunately, United have the chance to replace the 31-year-old in the short term and address their midfield issues early in the transfer window. Ruben Neves is a name that has been consistently mentioned as a potential target for United, dating back to his time at Wolves.

Now plying his trade at Al-Hilal, the 28-year-old is being linked with a return to the Premier League after turning down a new contract in Saudi Arabia. The Times has reported that Al-Hilal are resigned to losing him on a free transfer in the summer and are now open to selling him in January in an attempt to recoup some of the £47million they paid for him in 2023.

A price tag of £18m has been suggested, but it's thought that clubs showing interest could secure the Portuguese star for significantly less, potentially offering United a bargain deal for the start of 2026. headline: Ruben Amorim has already explained his reason for upsetting Man Utd star who 'didn't look happy'
body: Ruben Amorim has already offered an explanation after appearing to upset Joshua Zirkzee during Manchester United's 2-1 loss to Aston Villa. The Dutchman came off the bench in the defeat but perhaps expected to be introduced earlier than he was.

United found themselves trailing on the stroke of half-time during their trip to Villa Park after Morgan Rogers' sublime curling effort. Matheus Cunha levelled prior to the break, but Rogers added a second just before the hour mark and secured all three points for Unai Emery's side.

A casualty of the loss was captain Bruno Fernandes, who suffered what appeared to be a hamstring injury during the first half but continued playing. Zirkzee was a frontrunner to replace him at the interval but United icon Gary Neville was "surprised" to see Lisandro Martinez come on in his place.

Neville stated that Zirkzee looked upset at not being brought on at half-time, despite being introduced after 73 minutes, but Amorim provided an applicable explanation for a similar decision last season.
"I'm surprised as I thought Zirkzee would come on as he is closer to Fernandes' position," he said before adding: "He [Zirkzee] doesn't look like he's too happy."

But a not dissimilar situation occurred last campaign. Zirkzee started a tie against Newcastle in December 2024 but with United trailing 2-0 after 32 minutes, he was brought off the pitch and looked visibly distraught.

Amorim explained after the match: "You have to think about the team. The player is suffering during the game. We needed another midfielder. It was tough on me to do that. I talked with Joshua about that.

"I'm always thinking about the team. At that moment it was important for him to come out. I know that Josh is a really good guy. When he went to the tunnel, I can understand that some guys can be in a bad way but he is a really good lad."
He added: "It is life, and we will support Josh and continue. Newcastle were better than Manchester United. They weren't better than Josh."

Neville also had his say during this controversial substitution, much like he did when Zirkzee was not introduced against Villa. He said: "I know that he's earning a lot of money but there's a human being in there that's basically being cheered off by his home fans and that is brutal."
Despite Amorim making decisions surrounding Zirkzee for the good of the team, the Dutchman continues to be linked with a move away from the club.

Zirkzee was only signed in July 2024 from Bologna for £36.5million, but reports suggest he could make a swift return to Italy. Corriere dello Sport claim Roma are interested in Zirkee and the only thing currently preventing a transfer is a disparity on fees.

headline: MARSHALL: Where would Manchester United be without Bruno Fernandes? One thing is clear
body: How do you solve a problem like Bruno? In a week when Manchester United had to consider the possibility of losing their best player after his unexpected comments about his future, they are about to get a taste of what life without Fernandes might actually be like.

The 31-year-old reckons United's powerbrokers wanted to sell him last summer but lacked the "courage" to go through with it. His performances this season have once again made him indispensable, but after picking up a hamstring injury at Aston Villa, he now faces a spell on the sidelines.
What are the patterns they can take from those four defeats? These are the games and what sticks out from a Fernandes-less United.

Fernandes wasn't really missing back in May. He was at the Gtech Community Stadium, but spent the whole game sat on the bench. It summed up how United's focus had turned away from the Premier League and towards the Europa League.

Amorim's selection shows how priorities had changed and maybe this game belongs in a category of its own. There were starts for Tyler Fredricson, Harry Amass and Chido Obi. United added gloss to the scoreline but were 4-1 down with eight minutes to go. Mason Mount, Alejandro Garnacho and Amad got the goals and only one of that trio will be available on Boxing Day.

With Fernandes absent, it was Kobbie Mainoo who played next to Manuel Ugarte, another option that is off the table against Newcastle. Amad came on at half-time and he and Garnacho provided some spark to the attack, but that won't be possible now.

Maybe the most relevant game of them all, given Newcastle will be the first opponents United confront without Fernandes. The captain was suspended after being sent off against Wolves, and this was a grim day nobody wants to remember.

Newcastle were 2-0 up inside 20 minutes and it felt like they declared after that. Joshua Zirkzee was hooked after 33 minutes and booed off. Casemiro was given such a run around that it felt like it might be the end for him at Old Trafford.

United mustered just one shot on target as they lost for the fourth game in a row. "It is a really difficult moment, one of the more difficult moments in the history of Manchester United and we have to address it with honesty," Amorim said after the game.

On this occasion, it was Casemiro and Christian Eriksen in midfield, but the ageing duo were run ragged by Sandro Tonali, Joelinton and Bruno Guimaraes. That trio will be licking their lips at the chance to inflict more damage on the United midfield.

The second of two successive games that Fernandes missed with a knee injury. This time, United managed two shots on target and were comfortably held at bay by an Arsenal side still pushing for the title.

United went into the game with a midfield trio of Sofyan Amrabat, Mainoo and Scott McTominay, while Erik ten Hag finally handed a chance to Amad. That is at least something to emerge from the wreckage of the defeats without Fernandes.
There was a lack of creativity on show and with injuries forcing Ten Hag to field Jonny Evans and Casemiro together in the centre of defence, United did well to keep the score down to one.
That was a marked improvement from what happened at Selhurst Park six days earlier. This was a defeat that should have sounded the death knell for the Ten Hag era.

United were ripped to shreds in South London, when Palace had four goals by the 66th minute and could have easily had more. It remains one of the worst nights in the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era, which is saying something.

Palace racked up 10 shots on target to a pitiful two for United, who played with no intensity or imagination. A midfield of Mainoo, Eriksen and Mount might look good on paper, but they were trampled all over.
Ten Hag insisted after the game that "I will keep fighting" and somehow United beat Manchester City in the FA Cup final a few weeks later. Thankfully, Fernandes was fit for that one.
Four games without Fernandes and four defeats. Three of them without scoring, and two of them scoring highly on the embarrassment scale. It doesn't bode well.
United managed 10 shots on target in those four games, but half of those were in the chaotic game at Brentford, which had a significant end-of-season vibe.

Across those four games, United created an expected goals (xG) tally of 3.2, of which around half came at Brentford. Fernandes might be playing a deeper role, but he is still miles clear when it comes to creating chances and in his absence, it's pretty clear that there will be fewer opportunities, which is going to put a premium on taking them.

headline: MARSHALL: United have eight candidates to fill two Bruno Fernandes roles vs Newcastle
body: It's going to be a strange experience for Bruno Fernandes on Boxing Day when he sits down to watch Manchester United and is unable to influence the action. Whether Fernandes has his hamstring wrapped up in the warm at home, or has his big coat on at Old Trafford, he isn't going to know what to do with himself when his teammates take on Newcastle United.

Fernandes is 31 and a veteran of 683 appearances for club and country, but astonishingly, he has missed only four games in his career through injury. Two of those were for Portugal in the March 2019 international break and then two for United in May 2024. He has missed two more games due to illness, in 2017 and 2022, and that is it.

It's a remarkable injury record, but one that was unlikely to last as age caught up with the durable Portugal international. The sight of him clutching his hamstring just before half-time at Villa Park on Sunday confirmed Ruben Amorim's worst fears.

Amorim will offer an update on Fernandes' fitness when he holds his pre-Newcastle press conference on Christmas Eve, but he is expected to be absent for around a month. Amorim might also offer a few clues as to how he might replace his captain, although he is arguably irreplaceable.

Fernandes has again been the beating heart of this team this season. Playing slightly ahead of Casemiro, he has 12 goal involvements in 17 Premier League games and set the tone for performances, as he often does.
Amorim has two issues now. How to replace Fernandes in the team and who to hand the captain's armband to. Let's start with the first problem.

In truth, there aren't a lot of options. Kobbie Mainoo will be frustrated that a calf problem has denied him the chance to earn a first start of the season. Amorim has said all season that the 20-year-old is competing for a place with Fernandes, but now he finds himself sitting next to him in the physio's room.

That only leaves Casemiro and Manuel Ugarte. The former will return to the team after serving a suspension on Sunday and perhaps the Uruguayan will keep his place. That would likely mean Casemiro being given the freedom to get forward in the way that Fernandes does.

Amorim ruled out Lisandro Martinez as a regular midfield option last month, but the Argentine looked good there at Villa Park. He is only going to play the holding role, however, and is currently competing with Ugarte for that position.

If Amorim wants a more progressive option, he could turn to 18-year-old Jack Fletcher, who came on for the final 17 minutes on Sunday, or drop Mason Mount back from his position as one of the No. 10s. That would mean Joshua Zirkzee coming in alongside Matheus Cunha. The knock-on effect is that United would have no senior attacking options on the bench.
Amorim will also have to decide who to hand the captain's armband to. It was Diogo Dalot who took it for the second half at Villa and he described that as "a very proud moment".

The only game Fernandes hasn't started this season was the Carabao Cup defeat to Grimsby, when Harry Maguire was skipper, but Maguire is now absent with a thigh problem. In the Premier League, the last time Fernandes didn't start was at Brentford in May, when Luke Shaw was captain. Maguire and Diogo Dalot were also missing that day as focus turned to the Europa League.

At Wolves, a couple of weeks earlier, it was the now departed Victor Lindelof who captained United. The only other time Fernandes didn't start in the league last season was against Newcastle nearly a year ago, when Lisandro Martinez wore the armband. That's four different captains in four Premier League games without Fernandes in 2024/25.

The fact that Dalot was captain while Shaw and Martinez were on the pitch would suggest he is now ahead of them. He is in the six-man leadership group named in the summer, alongside Fernandes, Tom Heaton, Noussair Mazraoui, Martinez and Maguire. Of that six, Dalot is the only guaranteed starter on Boxing Day and the only other player from that group who could feature is Martinez.

Casemiro was suspended against Aston Villa but has some leadership experience. He has captained Brazil on 18 occasions, although never skippered Real Madrid. He has worn the armband twice from the off against United, in a 4-0 Premier League defeat to Crystal Palace and a 3-0 Carabao Cup loss to Newcastle.
So everything points to Dalot getting the captaincy in Fernandes' absence. Who replaces him in midfield might be a little trickier.

headline: MARSHALL: Antoine Semenyo, midfield transfers, academy call-ups and more - Man United questions answered
body: Welcome along to our latest Manchester United question and answer session with senior club writer Tyrone Marshall, who covers the daily goings-on at Old Trafford.

It's been another busy week in M16. A 4-4 draw with Bournemouth last week, a 2-1 defeat to Aston Villa on Sunday, speculation around the future of Kobbie Mainoo and an injury for Bruno Fernandes, not to mention attempts to sign Antoine Semenyo.

We asked for questions and you delivered. The responses to those submitted are below. We will be running weekly question and answer sessions from now, so keep an eye on our social media feeds and get your questions in as we seek to keep you plugged in to everything going on at Old Trafford.

Appreciating that we don't want to completely undermine the summer budget, how feasible is it that we could trigger Semenyo's release clause and still look at a loan-with-an-option deal for someone like Conor Gallagher?

From a budget point of view, I think that would be doable. The question is whether they want someone like Conor Gallagher. The noise coming out of United is that they will only move for long-term targets next month, which essentially means bringing forward a deal for someone they had lined up in the summer.

Semenyo ticks that box. They looked at him earlier this year, remained interested and would have waited until next summer but for the fact that his release clause meant there was suddenly a queue for him. I believe his release clause might be smaller in the summer, but nobody can afford to wait now.

I don't see United being able to get the calibre of midfielder they want in the summer on loan this winter. Someone like Gallagher or Ruben Neves might tick a box as a short-term, emergency option, but even Ruben Amorim said on Sunday they were keen to avoid making mistakes and would rather suffer short-term pain than make a transfer mistake.
When will the manager give more of the young players a chance instead of buying expensive flops?

To be fair to Amorim, he has given young players a go. As he pointed out, Toby Collyer, Harry Amass and Chido Obi got chances last season. I don't think any of them could say they have been harshly treated.

Collyer has had injury issues since, and Amass is doing well at a struggling Sheffield Wednesday. He will come on for the experience but I don't think anyone thinks he's ready for first-team football at Old Trafford. Chido struggled to influence first-team games last term and isn't exactly knocking the door down now.

There are question marks over how many players at academy level are ready to step up and I don't think Amorim is alone in having doubts. United have made costly mistakes in the market in recent years, but under Amorim, their record looks to have improved.
Senne Lammens looks like a solid signing and Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha look like very good deals. Benjamin Sesko has had a slow start, but there have been flashes of quality.
Fans always want to see young players, especially when a team is struggling, but I don't think the answer lies in youth at the moment.
When was the last time United made a profit from selling a player they had bought? They always seem to take heavy losses when selling " flops".

I think the clue is in the question. If you are selling a flop, you aren't going to make a profit on him. It goes without saying that a player's value will have shrunk if they have been a disappointment since signing.

I often think the discourse around United's ability to sell players is a little overplayed. They could certainly get better at it, but Manchester United aren't a selling club. There are usually only two reasons for United to sell, A) that player isn't good enough for the club, or B) they want to move elsewhere (such as Cristiano Ronaldo).

It isn't always that clear-cut, of course, but let's look at a couple of recent departures. Antony and Aaron Wan-Bissaka were poor signings who were never likely to live up to their price tag. That is a failure of recruitment rather than selling.

Aside from academy graduates, one of the last players United made a profit on was Daniel James, but that was always a weird deal. He was never likely to make the grade, improved a little and was 'flipped' for a profit. That is what you expect of Brighton or Brentford, not Manchester United.
Manchester United should not go for a defensive midfielder in this January transfer window. But if we can get the Antoine Semenyo deal done, then it will be considered a good window.

I think if United finish this window with just Semenyo, then it will be a good month. There is fierce competition for his signature but he would follow the trend of Cunha and Mbeumo as Premier League-proven players ready to 'plug and play' under Amorim, even if he ends up playing left wing-back.

There is a concern at the lack of options in midfield and it feels like all four midfielders have question marks over their futures beyond the summer, but United are determined not to panic. They are planning a midfield rebuild in 2026 and it might have to wait until the summer, when we can expect similar sums to the £200m+ spent on forwards in 2025 to be splashed on midfielders.
Did United receive any compensation from the FA for Luke Shaw being injured for months after ridiculously playing for England at the Euros?
FIFA's Club Protection Programme covers the salary of anyone injured on international duty. They must be out for a period of at least 28 consecutive days and the scheme is capped at €7.5million.

However, Luke Shaw was not injured on international duty in 2024. You could argue he rushed back to play for England, having missed the last three months of the season for United, but which professional footballer wouldn't want to play in a major tournament final for their country?

It's worth remembering that Shaw played the full 90 minutes in England's Euro 2024 final against Spain. He played 42 minutes against Switzerland in the quarter-finals and 45 minutes against the Netherlands in the semi-final. He returned to pre-season training at Carrington on time.

It was while wearing United training kit that he picked up another injury. Maybe that was due to the efforts made to get fit for England, but we can't be sure. What we can say is that those problems look to be a thing of the past and his fitness record this season has been exceptional.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United transfer gamble shows they are learning lessons of the past
body: If Manchester United need an example of a January transfer deal that turned out to be a success, then they only need to look at the captain they are now dreading being without for a week. Bruno Fernandes arrived in January 2020 and is the best signing the club have made in any transfer window for a long, long time.

Those sorts of success stories can be few and far between, but the secret to success in the mid-season market is not to get blown off course. The deals that turn out to be good ones are usually a case of a club fulfilling a long-standing interest in a player, rather than rushing into short-term or panicked deals.

Far too often, United's recent January business has tended towards the latter. The jury is open on last season's mid-season window dealings. Ayden Heaven had a good start to his United career but still has plenty to learn and after a shaky spell, Patrick Dorgu was much improved when returning to the team against Aston Villa on Sunday.

Maybe, in time, those will look like January steals, although United were shopping in the sales a year ago, so tight was their precarious financial situation. The purse strings are a little looser now and a £65million deal for Antoine Semenyo would fit the Fernandes mould. He is a player they have long admired and are making a move now because he is set to leave Bournemouth next month.

But that was not the case when loan moves were made for Wout Weghorst and Marcel Sabitzer in the winter of 2023, or Odion Ighalo in 2020. They might have been loans, but they don't come without a cost and all of them speak to poor squad planning.

Amorim was asked about January plans at Villa Park, in the wake of seeing his captain go off injured, an extremely rare sight in the career of Fernandes, who has missed two games in nearly six years at Old Trafford. His answer might have disappointed fans desperate for a raft of activity next month, but it was sensible and reassuring for those keen to see a new outlook on recruitment.

"What we cannot do is to reach January and try to do everything in urgency and make mistakes," he said. "And then here we go again with a lot of mistakes. I'm not going to get with Jason [Wilcox] and Omar [Berrada] and I'm going to say we need a lot of players because we have a plan.

"If we have to suffer, the club comes first. Of course, we are in the moment that we need points, but we need to find solutions and we are going to continue with our plan. Of course, you can feel that in this moment we are going to struggle, but we'll see."

We've seen plans change before, but it certainly sounds like Amorim is determined not to go down the short-term fix route. His reference to the mistakes of the past is accurate and those deals have got United nowhere. Loan moves in the middle of the season are unlikely to significantly enhance the quality of this squad.

Amorim would rather face short-term pain, whether that be turning to the academy or getting creative with his squad, such as fielding Lisandro Martinez in midfield. The risk is that it compromises the ambition of qualifying for the Champions League, but then who could add enough quality to strengthen that aim next month, without breaking the bank?
Maybe United will suffer for a little while. Amorim is banking that in the long run, focusing finances on targets that really will add quality will pay off. It sounds like a sensible strategy.
